communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #11022021
communications.communication:
PRR 11022021-Anon
Dear Anonymous requestor:
Clarification Questions (repeated and follow-ups):

1.                   Regarding clarification question 1:
“Please define what you intend by “of.” A reasonable interpretation of that would be that you are seeking records “from” the above individuals.”
Your answer included this comment:
Regarding the requested public record communications "of" and "from" the previously referenced individuals . . ..
It appears that your answer is that you intend “of” to mean “from.” The District will proceed in that manner unless you advise otherwise.

2.                   Please allow me to explain that In general, email records of each of the named individuals will be searched and produced separately by individual. Some of the search results may be combined in order to avoid a high number of duplications.  The District will retain discretion in this regard in order to process your request most efficiently.
Assuming separate production sets for each individual and some combined groups as appropriate, please advise if you would like to prioritize the individuals listed. The District will try to honor any such priorities, within parameters that are consistent with the most efficient processing of your request.

3.                   You have asked for records to be produced in reverse chronological order, stating that you prefer the District to produce emails first. To clarify, are you asking that all email records back to 1.1.19 for an individual be produced before any records are produced for another individual?

4.                   You did not respond to the questions numbered 3 and 4 (renumbered below due to formatting loss in your reply message) regarding targeting your request. As noted, targeting does not limit your request. Rather, it allows you to prioritize so that the records which will be most meaningful to you in support of your purpose will be produced to you before others. I understand this may be important to you in view of the volume of records you are requesting. For example, in searches performed to date, the number of potentially responsive emails from one individual was 38,743.  Others were in the 28,000 to 36,000 range.



I would be glad to discuss your request with you if it would be helpful. I am often able to help requestors target their requests when I have a better understanding of their priorities.

Please be advised that production of emails in .pst format is not possible. Every record is reviewed for applicable exemptions, and appropriate redactions will be applied prior to the production of records to you. The redaction process occurs only in a .pdf format. Each individual message is converted to a .pdf format.

Your answers to these questions are due on or before December 17, 2021. The timing of your answers may affect the timing of the District’s responses to your request. Additional clarification questions may arise in the course of responding to your request.

I am glad to assist you in accessing records that will be meaningful to you.
Best regards,

Helen A. Boyer
Public Records Officer
Bellevue School District No. 405
425-456-4101
publicrecords@bsd405.org<mailto:publicrecords@bsd405.org>

Thank you for the prompt response. Getting clarification of your request is important, to be sure we have a mutual understanding.

Clarification Questions

communications.communication:
Hello,

We have no way of knowing what email accounts the District has in it’s possession for each of the listed individuals conducting public business e.g. Superintendent Dr. Art Jarvis email: JarvisA@bsd405.org . 

We also have no way of knowing what personal or 3rd party email accounts District personnel and Board members may use to conduct public business which are also subject to this records request - possibilities include email:art.jarvis@gmail.com and email: artjarvis@yahoo.com.

We have requested all email communications for a specific period of time by individual. This would include ALL email accounts used by these individuals to conduct public business. The “to” and “from” address fields are irrelevant. 

All that is relevant it the email address account itself, and if the date of the email communication falls within the date range requested.  

No search need be conducted – archive or copy the entire email account for the dates requested and produce the result preferably in .PST format. 

As for “deleting” correspondence history – you are mistaken. Nothing has been “deleted.” 

We have done the best we can to answer your questions in detail. 

We answered your 11-9-21 questions on 11-11-11, a copy of which is below. 

We do not receive an email “thread” nor any “highlights” just plain text of your email on the date you send it.

Please clearly restate any questions you continue to have regarding this records request and we can resend our previous responses to you.

Thank you.

*************************************

11/11/2021

communications.subject: PRR 10122021-Anon RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #11022021
communications.communication:
PRR 10122021-Anon
Dear Anonymous requestor:
Thank you.
Clarification questions:

  1.  When you use the phrase communications “of” an individual, are you referring to:

  1.  communications “from” that individual? Please answer yes or no.

When you use the phrase communications “of” an individual, are you referring to:

  1.  communications “to” that individual? Please answer yes or no.

When you use the phrase communications “of” an individual, are you referring to:

  1.  communications “copied to” that individual? Please answer yes or no.



  1.  You have not responded to the following questions sent to you on 11.9.21, numbered 3 and 4 in that message. This is the District’s third request for a response to these questions:


3.       It is apparent that your request seeks a very substantial body of records. In the District’s efforts to serve you fully and as efficiently as possible, please consider specifying particular records of interest to you, or at the very least prioritize the records you are seeking in some way that will assist you in determining whether in fact you need all of the records described. For example, you could specify a topic, keywords, or a more narrow date range. You could specify a more targeted group of records to be produced first, while retaining the broader request in case it is needed.

Requestors are required to specify records requested so they are reasonably locatable. While the records you have described are locatable, the volume is extensive. The volume will affect the time required to produce the records.

4.       I will assume at this time, consistent with the purposes of the Public Records Act, that you are seeking records that are meaningful to you regarding the conduct of the District, and for a legitimate purpose that will not interfere with the efficient administration of the District. Although you are not required under the law to disclose that purpose, I invite you to do so, so that I can assist you in targeting your request to that purpose. If your request is targeted, it will be much easier for you to find records that are meaningful to you within the body of produced records.


In reminding you om 11.17.21 to respond to questions 3 and 4, I explained the importance to you of your answering these questions:

As noted, targeting does not limit your request. Rather, it allows you to prioritize so that the records which will be most meaningful to you in support of your purpose will be produced to you before others. I understand this may be important to you in view of the volume of records you are requesting. For example, in searches performed to date, the number of potentially responsive emails from one individual was 38,743. Others were in the 28,000 to 36,000 range.

I would be glad to discuss your request with you if it would be helpful. I am often able to help requestors target their requests when I have a better understanding of their priorities.
Thank you for clarifying your request at the outset. It is essential that we have a mutual understanding. Additional clarifications may arise in the course of processing your request. Your answers to the questions above are due on or before December 17, 2021. The timing of your answers will affect the timing of the District’s response.

Missing correspondence history
Please review the message you sent on 11.19.21 at 1:39 PM, and the message you sent on 11.18.21. In each of those messages, portions of the correspondence history between you and this office were missing, including but not limited to the 11.9.21 message to you containing the clarification questions above, to which you have not yet responded.
Perhaps this is a technical aberration of the service you are using. If necessary, please work with Muckrock to determine why portions of correspondence history related to your request may not be retained when you reply to a message. For example, your 11.19.21 message immediately below contains a history that skips from your message dated 11.02.21 to your message dated 11.11.21. Please take steps to prevent that from occurring in the future.


Public Records Request Process

You state:

“No search need be conducted – archive or copy the entire email account for the dates requested and produce the result preferably in .PST format.”



Please allow me to help you understand public record response procedures, so that your expectations can be realistic. When a request for records is made, the District conducts a search for potentially responsive records. When potentially responsive records are assembled, each record is reviewed to determine whether it is responsive, and if so, whether the law requires that exemptions be applied to it. If some or all of a record is exempt, the District applies redactions to that record or withholds it, and then describes to the requestor the basis for any exemptions that were applied. As noted below, it is not possible to produce records in .PST format, because records must first be converted to .PDF format in order to apply redactions to them.

For these reasons, it is not possible to “copy” the contents of “an entire email account” and produce all emails within such a an account to you. Each email must first be reviewed, analyzed, and processed for production.

As noted in my 11.09.021 message to you, your request will be completed in a series of installments. Due to the procedures described above, only a limited number of email records can be produced per installment. Each request is unique, but given the workload of this office, email records can be generally processed at a rate of perhaps 30-100 individual emails per installment. Installments may occur at varying intervals, which can be 30 days or more. These processing volume rates vary widely based on the nature of the request and other factors.
As stated above, during the nearly 3-year period you have identified, one of the persons on your list sent 38,743 emails—that is 38,743 emails were “from” that person. There may be some duplications within that number. However, even if that number was significantly reduced to something in the range of 20,000 emails, and assuming a rate of processing those records at 100 per month, it could take 200 months, or more than 16 years, to process only the emails “from” that one person on your list.

I am taking the time to explain this to you in detail, at the beginning of processing your request, so that you can understand how important it is to you, assuming your intention is to receive records that are meaningful to you and relate to a legitimate purpose, to limit your request by targeting it in some way as described in questions 3 and 4 above. I can help you find the needle in the haystack that you really want. You do not need to ask for the haystack to achieve your legitimate purpose.

I am available to assist you in exploring options by which you can limit your request so that it will yield records that will be meaningful to you, while retaining your broader request in case it is needed.
Best regards,

Helen A. Boyer
Public Records Officer
Bellevue School District No. 405
425-456-4101
publicrecords@bsd405.org<mailto:publicrecords@bsd405.org>

communications.communication:

Dear Requestor:
On behalf of the Bellevue School District, I am making a first installment in response to your request for records. You requested emails to be produced in reverse chron order, in 6 month blocks, to/from/cc the following persons in this following order:

Superintendent Dr. Ivan Duran
Superintendent Dr. Art Jarvis
Assistant Superintendent Human Resources, Jeff Thomas
Chief Communications and Engagement Officer, Janine Thorn
Director Equity and Strategic Engagement, Shomari Jones
Executive Director for District and Community Affairs, John Harrison
Director of Research, Evaluation and Assessment Naomi Calvo
Deputy Superintendent Student Academic Performance and Instructional Leadership, Eva Collins
Deputy Superintendent Finance and Operations, Melissa deVita
District 1 School Board Member Sima Sarrafan
District 2 School Board Member Carolyn Watson
District 3 School Board Member Erica Melief
District 4 School Board Member Christine Chew
District 5 School Board Member Francine Wiest
Director of Program Office, Melanie McGee
Executive Director Teaching and Learning, Sharon Kautz
Executive Director Teaching and Learning, Heather Edlund
Executive Director of Schools, Patty Siegwarth
Executive Director of Schools, Kelly Aramaki
Executive Director of Schools, Heather Sánchez
Executive Director of Schools, Gloria Henderson
To give you a sense of the volume of records you have requested, searches of potentially responsive records for the following persons for the first six-month period, 05 01 21 through 11 02 21, returned the following numbers of potentially responsive messages to be reviewed and processed for production to you:

Superintendent Dr. Ivan Duran                                                                   8420
Superintendent Dr. Art Jarvis                                                                      7245
Assistant Superintendent Human Resources, Jeff Thomas              25,244
Chief Communications and Engagement Officer, Janine Thorn     13.443
Total for these 4 individuals, 05 01 21-11 02 21:                                  53,952

This installment includes emails to/from/cc Superintendent Ivan Duran for the period 10 01 21-10 14 21. This is roughly the first half of the month of October 2021, consisting of 446 messages. The period 10 15 21-11 02 21 will be the subject of the next installment.

The records are being produced to you via Box, from which you may retrieve, view, and download records. Please click the link below to retrieve the following records:
NOTE: I am having technical difficulties creating this link. I will complete this process as soon as possible.

Please note that Dr. Duran has not been employed by the District since the spring of 2021. As a result, there are no messages from him in this group. The vast majority of messages are commercial solicitations, newsletters or subscriptions; messages on which Dr. Duran was copied because his name may not have yet been deleted from a distribution group; or messages from persons who did not know of his status.

My observation in processing your request to date is that it could be completed more efficiently if you limited the volume of potentially responsive records to retrieve messages that are more likely to be of interest to you. This could be accomplished in a number of ways. For example, you could consider redefining “communications of” to mean “to” or “from” but not “cc”; limiting the date range; limiting the request to one or more topics of interest; identifying key words; and/or agreeing that commercial solicitations, newsletters, and subscriptions would not be responsive.
No redactions were made to these records.

I estimate the next installment for February 25, 2022.
In order to expedite the District’s response to your request, please consider limiting the request to a reasonable volume that is more likely to be of interest to you, as suggested above.
Best regards,

Helen A. Boyer

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request #11022021, Installment 2
communications.communication:
PRR 11022021-Anon
Dear Requestor:
On behalf of the Bellevue School District, I am making a second installment in response to your request for records. You requested emails to be produced in reverse chron order, in 6 month blocks, to/from/cc the following persons in this following order:

Superintendent Dr. Ivan Duran
Superintendent Dr. Art Jarvis
Assistant Superintendent Human Resources, Jeff Thomas
Chief Communications and Engagement Officer, Janine Thorn
Director Equity and Strategic Engagement, Shomari Jones
Executive Director for District and Community Affairs, John Harrison
Director of Research, Evaluation and Assessment Naomi Calvo
Deputy Superintendent Student Academic Performance and Instructional Leadership, Eva Collins
Deputy Superintendent Finance and Operations, Melissa deVita
District 1 School Board Member Sima Sarrafan
District 2 School Board Member Carolyn Watson
District 3 School Board Member Erica Melief
District 4 School Board Member Christine Chew
District 5 School Board Member Francine Wiest
Director of Program Office, Melanie McGee
Executive Director Teaching and Learning, Sharon Kautz
Executive Director Teaching and Learning, Heather Edlund
Executive Director of Schools, Patty Siegwarth
Executive Director of Schools, Kelly Aramaki
Executive Director of Schools, Heather Sánchez
Executive Director of Schools, Gloria Henderson
This installment includes emails to/from/cc Superintendent Ivan Duran for the period 10 15 21 through 10 21 2021. It includes 227 messages. The period 10 22 2021 through 11 02 2021 will be the subject of the next installment.

The records are being produced to you via Box, from which you may retrieve, view, and download records, within 30 days of receipt. A link will be provided to you to access the records in a message that will follow shortly.

Please note that Dr. Duran has not been employed by the District since the spring of 2021. As a result, there are no messages from him in this group. The vast majority of messages are commercial solicitations, newsletters or subscriptions; messages on which Dr. Duran was copied because his name may not have yet been deleted from a distribution group; or messages from persons who did not know of his status.

Your request could be completed more efficiently if you limited the volume of potentially responsive records to retrieve messages that are more likely to be of interest to you. This could be accomplished in a number of ways. For example, you could consider redefining “communications of” to mean “to” or “from” but not “cc”; limiting the number of persons whose communications are sought; limiting the date range; limiting the request to one or more topics of interest; identifying key words; and/or agreeing that commercial solicitations, newsletters, and subscriptions would not be responsive.

Redactions were made to one record in this set, consistent with exemptions set forth in the Public Records Act. Redactions are indicated by blocked out text with an overlying code. I have also attached to this message a Redaction and Exemption Codes chart that explains the basis for the exemptions that applied.  If there are any records that contain marked out texts that do not have an overlying code, that is the form in which the record was received by the District.

I estimate the next installment for March 30, 2022.
In order to expedite the District’s response to your request, please consider limiting the request to a reasonable volume that is more likely to be of interest to you, as suggested above.
Best regards,

Helen A. Boyer
Public Records Officer
Bellevue School District No. 405
425-456-4101
publicrecords@bsd405.org<mailto:publicrecords@bsd405.org>

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request #11022021
communications.communication:
PRR 11022021-Anon-Muckrock
Dear Requestor:
The Bellevue School District is not withholding any records from you.
Please direct all messages pertaining to your request to the public records mailbox, publicrecords@bsd405.org.
The automated correspondence features of the Muckrock site are not an efficient way to correspond or to review correspondence. Please do not interrupt our correspondence history by cutting messages out of the email string. I know that history can get long. However, it is important in order for us to communicate effectively that an accurate history of our communications is readily available to both of us.
Please allow me to summarize our recent correspondence:

Feb 25–email from BSD, making second installment consisting of 227 emails, and providing link to Box for records.
Feb 26—confirmation from Box site to BSD that you accepted and opened link to records.
June 29—email from you, stating you had received only one installment, on 1.9.22.
June 29–email from BSD, setting a next installment for July 21.
July 15—email from you, inquiring as to status. Appears to be automated Muckrock email. June 29 message from BSD does not appear to have been read.
July 21—email from BSD, inquiring further about your statement on June 29 that you had received only one installment, and listing two installments that were produced. Attached your 2.26.22 acceptance of link to second installment provided via Box site. Advised that estimated installment intended for July 21 would be extended to July 22.
July 25, 26, 28 – emails from BSD, extending estimated dates from July 22 to August 1, with explanations.
Aug 3–email from you, explaining (for the first time) that you were not able to open the link to records that were sent to you on 2.25.22.

Installment 2 Produced to You Again
First, let’s take care of your receipt of the records in the February 25 installment. You were advised in a February 25 email that a link to the records was on its way to you. I received confirmation on February 26 that you accepted and opened the link that was sent to you. Now, on August 3, you explain for the first time that you were not able to retrieve records in the link that was provided to you. If you had let me know in February that you had difficulty retrieving the records, we could have resolved it at that time. I recognize there may be glitches with technology. I am glad to work with you to resolve them promptly, if you let me know.

Each installment is made available to you for 30 days. In the future, if you do not acknowledge and accept receipt of records within 30 days after they are made available to you, your request will be closed as abandoned.

I am re-sending you the records that were provided to you in installment 2 on February 25, 2021. I will attach these to two emails to you, due to their volume.

Installment 2 consisted of 227 email records covering a period of October 15-21, 2021, in zip folders are follows:
2021 10 15_10 19, Duran, 122 (attached here)
2021 10 20_10 21, Duran, 105 (will be attached to an email that follows)

The second zip folder includes a record that contains information that is exempt from disclosure under the Public Records Act. Exempt information is redacted and marked with an overlay code. I will attach to the following email a Redaction and Exemption Codes chart that explains the basis of exemptions applied.

Progress on your high-volume request
Please appreciate the overall high volume of your request, when there are 227 email records in one week for one of your named recipients. Each individual email record you request must be retrieved from archives, reviewed for applicability to your request and for exemptions, and then prepared for production to you.
Due to typical operational capacity of this department, it is generally possible to process roughly 100 email records per installment, and to make installments to a requestor every 60 to 90 days. These are general capacity numbers, which may be adjusted in different contexts for different types of requests. Most requestors seek specific information that is likely to be meaningful to them, which allows for effective and efficient request processing.
Your request, on the other hand, seeks a high volume of communications, from a large group of persons, with no specific focus or topic. As a result, the volume of records will be is very high, the retrieval time is extensive, and the review process is very time-consuming.
You have been provided 446 records in installment 1, Jan 19 2022; and 227 records in installment 2, February 25 2022, for a total of 673 records. This is well within standard processing rate.

Next Estimated Installment
The District attempts to meet its estimated installment dates. Sometimes that is not possible. If it is not possible to meet an estimated date, you will be provided an explanation and a revised estimated date.
The time it took to complete today’s correspondence was time the District was not able to devote to a next installment to you.
I estimate a next installment for September 1, 2022. That estimate takes into account factors of summer staff absences; staff absences for other reasons, including medical leaves; the current workload of this department; and the complexity of assembly and review required for your request as set forth above.
Best regards,

Helen A. Boyer
Public Records Officer
Bellevue School District No. 405
425-456-4101
publicrecords@bsd405.org<mailto:publicrecords@bsd405.org>

PRR 11022021-Anon-Muckrock

communications.subject: Introducing all-new Box Notes
communications.communication:
Service Notification



 
<https://www.box.com/home?utm_source=iterable&utm_medium=Email&utm_theme=CloudContentManagement&id=&utm_content=notes2-eng&utm_buid=18391578177>

 



Dear valued customer,



Box Notes is where people work together, securely and collaboratively, to 
achieve better results. And, we are excited to let you know that you will begin 
upgrading to the all-new Box Notes starting August 17, 2022.



All-new Box Notes supports a broader range of content collaboration activities 
and includes powerful enhancements for real-time collaboration and organization 
including

 * new content creation capabilities like advanced table functions, call-out 
boxes, and quote blocks
 * additional display and formatting options such as enhanced typography, 
image, and code blocks
 * more ways to  organize your content with automated table of contents and 
divider lines
 * and in-line cursors that help you keep track of collaborator edits for more 
productive and streamlined collaboration.


What you need to know about the upgrade

All-new Box Notes will be rolled out automatically to you. Once upgraded to 
the new experience, any Notes you create will be able to leverage all the 
fantastic features we’ve built. Existing notes will be automatically converted 
to the new experience with On-Demand Migration—meaning when an old Note is 
accessed, it will be converted to the new format—a process that takes 
milliseconds. After we complete the rollout of all-new Box Notes to all 
customers, we will migrate all remaining notes not covered by on-demand 
migration. 



Learn more about the all-new Box Notes with the following resources:

 * The product announcement 
<https://support.box.com/hc/en-us/articles/6990288241171-Introducing-all-new-Box-Notes?utm_source=iterable&utm_medium=Email&utm_theme=CloudContentManagement&id=&utm_content=notes2-eng&utm_buid=18391578177>
, which introduces all-new Box Notes
 * All-new Box Notes support article 
<https://support.box.com/hc/en-us/articles/360044195933-Introducing-Box-Notes?utm_source=iterable&utm_medium=Email&utm_theme=CloudContentManagement&id=&utm_content=notes2-eng&utm_buid=18391578177>
, which provides an overview of this new functionality
 * List of known issues 
<https://support.box.com/hc/en-us/articles/8427168240147?utm_source=iterable&utm_medium=Email&utm_theme=CloudContentManagement&id=&utm_content=notes2-eng&utm_buid=18391578177>
 that the team has uncovered during the upgrade process


This move will not cause any disruption to your Box instance or your users, 
but if you have any questions, please open a ticket with Box Product Support at
support.box.com 
<http://support.box.com/?utm_source=iterable&utm_medium=Email&utm_theme=CloudContentManagement&id=&utm_content=notes2-eng&utm_buid=18391578177>
.


Sincerely,
The Box team


You are receiving this operational email as the owner of your free Box 
account. If you have any questions, please reach out toBox Product Support. 
<https://support.box.com/hc/en-us/requests/new?utm_source=iterable&utm_medium=Email&utm_theme=CloudContentManagement&id=&utm_content=notes2-eng&utm_buid=18391578177>

communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

All current "Brady lists" and "Giglio lists" (per Brady v. Maryland/Giglio v. United States) maintained by your office.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

title: PIA Request - EV Charger Reports

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: PIA Request - EV Charger Reports
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, MD. Code Ann, Gen. Prov. ("GP) §§ 4-101-4-601, I hereby request all records in your custody and control pertaining to:

(A) Records relating to the maintenance and operations of DC fast chargers for electric vehicles under programs administered by the state of Maryland. This includes, but is not limited to, the operation and maintenance plans  submitted by grantees and any records concerning complaints, maintenance, and operational uptime of DC fast chargers that are funded or administered by the state of Maryland. I only seek records that have been generated on or after January 1, 2020.

(B) Grantee Quarterly Operation Reports for Q1, 2023 for DC Fast Charger programs administered by MEA.

If all or any part of this request is denied, I request that I be provided with a written explanation that includes the reason for the denial, the legal authority justifying the denial, and my appeal rights. If you determine that some portions of the requested records are exempt from disclosure, please provide me with the portions that can be disclosed.

I also request that, if appropriate, fees be waived as I believe this request is in the public interest. In the event that fees cannot be waived, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available.

Under GP § 4-203(b)(1), if a custodian determines that a record is responsive to a request and open to inspection, the custodian must produce the record “immediately” after receipt of the written request. An additional reasonable period “not to exceed 30 days” is available only where the additional period of time is required to retrieve the records and assess their status under the PIA. A custodian should not, however, wait the full 30 days to allow or deny access to a record if that amount of time is not needed to respond.

If access is to be granted, the record should be produced for inspection and copying promptly after the written request is evaluated. If it will take more than 10 working days to produce the requested records, the custodian must notify the requester, in writing or by email, of that fact. GP § 4-203(b)(2). The notification must be sent within the same 10-working-day time period and must indicate the amount of time needed to respond, the reason for the delay, and an estimate of the range of fees that may be charged.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within the time period prescribed in the statute.

Sincerely,

Lanny Hartmann

communications.subject: Re: Maryland Public Information Act Request: PIA Request - EV Charger Reports
communications.communication:
Lanny:

Thank you for contacting the Maryland Energy Administration

The Maryland Energy Administration has received your request for records
under the Public Information Act. For record keeping, your request at this
time is for the "(A) Records relating to the maintenance and operations of
DC fast chargers for electric vehicles under programs administered by the
state of Maryland. This includes, but is not limited to, the operation and
maintenance plans submitted by grantees and any records concerning
complaints, maintenance, and operational uptime of DC fast chargers that
are funded or administered by the state of Maryland. I only seek records
that have been generated on or after January 1, 2020.
(B) Grantee Quarterly Operation Reports for Q1, 2023 for DC Fast Charger
programs administered by MEA."

We will begin to process your request today.

We will contact you to notify you within ten working days if there is a

communications.subject: RE: Maryland Public Information Act Request: PIA Request - EV Charger Reports
communications.communication:
I wish to reiterate that I am seeking not only the quarterly reports as specified in (B) but also "records concerning complaints, maintenance, and operational uptime" as specified in (A) of my request letter. These would be documents including email correspondence between citizens and MEA and between MEA and grantees concerning broken or malfunctioning chargers. Examples of these documents can be found in MEA's October 13, 2021 response to my PIA request which was dated, September 13, 2021. One of the records sent had the file name: State of Maryland Mail - Re_ Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Program (EVIP)_Redacted.pdf  if that helps.

As requested in my June 9, 2023 request, do you have any records in your custody and control pertaining to:

(A) Records relating to the maintenance and operations of DC fast chargers for electric vehicles under programs administered by the state of Maryland. This includes, but is not limited to, the operation and maintenance plans submitted by grantees and any records concerning complaints, maintenance, and operational uptime of DC fast chargers that are funded or administered by the state of Maryland. I only seek records that have been generated on or after January 1, 2020.

title: Peekskill School District: Records Pertaining to Network Breaches or Cyber Attacks (2018-Present)

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Peekskill School District: Records Pertaining to Network Breaches or Cyber Attacks (2018-Present)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Jordan Lassiter
MuckRock News
DEPT MR 146407
263 Huntington Ave
Boston, MA 02115

Date: June 1, 2023

Peekskill City School District
1031 Elm Street
Peekskill, NY 10566

Attn: FOIA Officer

Subject: Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) Request – Records Pertaining to Network Breaches or Cyber Attacks 

Dear FOIA Officer,

Under the provisions of the New York Freedom of Information Law, Article 6 of the Public Officers Law, I hereby request access to and copies of all records held by Peekskill City School District pertaining to:

1. Any network breaches or cyber attacks that have occurred within your organization, including any records of unauthorized access, data theft, or system compromise from January 1, 2018 to the present.
2. Any internal investigations or reviews conducted in response to a suspected or confirmed network breach, including any reports, findings, or recommendations.
3. Any incident response plans or policies in place to address network breaches, including any procedures for mitigating and remediating the effects of such incidents.
4. Any communications between your organization and affected individuals, customers, or partners regarding network breaches or incidents.

Should any portion of the requested records be deemed exempt from disclosure, I request the release of any reasonably segregable non-exempt portions in accordance with the New York Freedom of Information Law. If an entire document is exempt, I request a justification, citing specific FOIA exemptions, and provision of an exemption log.

Please note your obligation under the law not to destroy any records potentially responsive to this request. Any withholding, redaction, or destruction of responsive records without proper justification constitutes a violation of the FOIA and is subject to litigation.

I also request a waiver of all fees in connection with this request as disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest because it is likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester. If the enclosed waiver is not accepted and there are any potential charges in excess of $200 associated with fulfilling my request, please inform me in advance.

As stipulated by the FOIA, I look forward to your response within five business days.

Thank you for your prompt attention to this matter.

Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter
Independent Investigative Journalist
TransparencyReport.pw
Email: Jordan@Lassiter.eu
Phone: 1-845-748-0329

Enclosure: Fee Waiver Request Letter

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

title: Suspected Shoplifting Incident at Walmart on April 22 2023

communications.subject: New York Freedom of Information Law Request: Suspected Shoplifting Incident at Walmart on April 22 2023
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New York Freedom of Information Law, I hereby request the following records:

Fishkill Town Clerk
807 Route 52, Room 114
Fishkill, NY 12524


Subject: Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) Request

Dear Fishkill Town Clerk:

Pursuant to the New York State Freedom of Information Law (FOIL) (Article 6 of the Public Officers Law), I hereby request access to and copies of the following records concerning the Fishkill Town Police Department:

The 911 audio recording of the call made to report a suspected shoplifting incident that occurred at Walmart, 26 W Merritt Blvd, Fishkill, NY 12524, on April 22,2023 specifically between the time frame of 6:00 PM and 7:00 PM.
Dashcam and body camera footage from the Fishkill Town Police Department officers who responded to the aforementioned suspected shoplifting incident.
Names and badge numbers of the Fishkill Town Police Department officers who responded to the suspected shoplifting incident.
Incident reports, including any narratives, witness statements, and evidence logs, generated by the Fishkill Town Police Department concerning the suspected shoplifting incident in question.
In accordance with the FOIL and relevant case law, including Westchester Rockland Newspapers v. Kimball (50 NY2d 575, 581 [1980]), Scott, Sardano & Pomeranz v. Records Access Officer of Syracuse (65 N.Y.2d 294 [1985]), and Matter of New York Times Co. v. City of NY Fire Dept. (4 N.Y.3d 477 [2005]), I kindly request that you do not withhold, redact, or delete any records or portions of records unless there is a specific and legitimate exemption under the New York State FOIL.

Please be aware that I am prepared to pursue legal action to compel the release of the requested records if they are unlawfully withheld, redacted, or deleted. It is my hope that we can resolve this request amicably and without the need for litigation.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jordan Lassiter

Sincerely,
Jordan Lassiter

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,
Rose Terse" A Public Records Officer of the Prosecuting Attorney's Office will be helping you with your records request. An initial search and review of records matching your request will be completed and reply will be posted within five (5) business days.  This reply will either provide the requested records, ask you for clarification of your request, provide an estimate of fees, or, if your request is broad and involves a large number of records, you’ll be provided a schedule of response installments. Please note, the State of Washington Public Records Act, Chapter 42.56 RCW, does not require a governmental body to create new information, to do legal research, or to answer questions. 
You can monitor the progress of your request in the Kittitas County Public Records Portal. title: Police Staff Roster (March 2023) (University of Washington Police)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Police Staff Roster (March 2023) (University of Washington Police)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Staff roster including but not limited to first and last names, job titles, areas of assignment, and badge, serial, and other identifying numbers. In order of preference, I would prefer that this data be provided as: plain text with comma-separated-values (i.e., a "CSV" file), OpenDocument spreadsheet, Excel spreadsheet, or the native electronic format of the software from which this information is retrieved in fulfillment of my request. I specifically request that you not create a new record for me by rendering to PDF or by printing your electronic record then scanning it to make a series of images of the printed data.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Rose Terse

Re: Public Records Request PR_2023_000355


Dear Requester:

The Office of Public Records and Open Public Meetings is seeking a partial clarification regarding your public records request received by this office on May 10, 2023. This clarification is sought as allowed by RCW 42.56.520 of the Public Records Act of Washington State; which states, in part:

[A]n agency may ask the requestor to clarify what information the requestor is seeking. If the requestor fails to respond to an agency request to clarify the request, the agency must respond to those portions of the request that are clear.

We seek clarification about: Are you seeking data regarding all employee or just employees that have "staff" as part of their job title/classification? Are you seeking records regarding University of Washington Seattle Campus or are you seeking records regarding UW Bothell and UW Tacoma as well?

Please contact this office by May 25, 2023 to clarify the portion of your request specified above. If we do not hear from you by that date, we will assume you are only interested in obtaining the portion(s) of your request that are clear and will fulfill your request accordingly.

Sincerely,


Susan Adams
Compliance Analyst

UNIVERSITY OF WASHINGTON
Office of Public Records and Open Public Meetings
Mail: Roosevelt Commons-Box 354997, Seattle, WA 98195
Street: 4311 11th Ave NE, #360

title: Texas DCJ Adult Pay to Stay Policy

communications.subject: Texas Public Information Act Request: Texas DCJ Adult Pay to Stay Policy
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Texas Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

The following materials regarding the imposition, assessment, collection and balances of inmate fees and debt:

All current policies and procedures regarding medical and room & board costs or fees for which inmates are or may become liable. Please include all policies and procedures related to how fees are set, accrued, imposed, collected, and enforced (such as those related to per diem fees, ability to pay determinations, penalties for late or non-payment, authorization for civil or criminal action for payment enforcement, etc). 

All reports, databases, spreadsheets, or equivalent materials regarding debts/restitution paid to or owed to this department or any facility/agency under its jurisdiction in FY2021. Please include all relevant data regarding medical and room & board costs, including the number of individuals charged for medical and room & board costs or fees and the total amount of medical and room & board fees imposed in FY2021.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kelly Stevenson

communications.subject: PIR - Kelly Stevenson - PIA No. 0883-06-2023
communications.communication:
Dear Kelly Stevenson:

On June 21, 2023, you submitted to the Texas Department of Criminal Justice a public information request seeking policies, procedures, and reports related to medical and room and board fees/costs for FY 2021:


  *   All current policies and procedures regarding medical and room & board costs or fees for which inmates are or may become liable. Please include all policies and procedures related to how fees are set, accrued, imposed, collected, and enforced (such as those related to per diem fees, ability to pay determinations, penalties for late or non-payment, authorization for civil or criminal action for payment enforcement, etc).



  *   All reports, databases, spreadsheets, or equivalent materials regarding debts/restitution paid to or owed  to this department or any facility/agency under its jurisdiction in FY2021. Please include all relevant data regarding medical and room & board costs, including the number of individuals charged for medical and room & board costs or fees and the total amount of medical and room & board fees imposed in FY2021.

The collections processed  by Commissary and Trust Fund and Accounting and Business Services for room and board and inmate medical fees are for fiscal year 2021.

Attached is Government Code 501.014, which relates to inmate money and Governor Abbott's waiver of health care fees, effective March 20, 2020. TDCJ did not assess new charges for medical visits in FY 2021 after March 20, 2020. For the attached Commissary & Trust Fund chart, note that "Charged" is an accumulated amount of medical fees charged and medical fees refunded to an inmate within the reporting month.  In FY 2021,  the agency did not assess new medical fees; therefore, the amount shown as a negative is the amount refunded to inmates for prior medical visits.  "Collected" is the total amount that is otherwise collected from an inmate trust fund account for a previously charged medical visit.
Room and Board is only collected for the Prison Industry Enhancement Program.

Also responsive to your request, see the attachment and the following URL:

https://www.tdcj.texas.gov/documents/Offender_Orientation_Handbook_English.pdf (pp. 39-40)

Our office now considers your request (0882-06-2023, which was inadvertently assigned a duplicate PIR number, 0883-06-2023) closed.

Thank you,

Office of the General Counsel-TDCJ
P: (936) 437-6700

The information contained in this email and any attachments is intended for the exclusive use of the addressee(s) and may contain confidential, privileged, or proprietary information. Any other use of these materials is strictly prohibited. This email shall not be forwarded outside the Texas Department of Criminal Justice, Office of the General Counsel, without the permission of the original sender. If you have received this material in error, please notify me immediately by telephone and destroy all electronic, paper, or other versions.

title: Health and mental healthcare and juvenile justice (Department Of Children, Youth And Families)

communications.subject: Rhode Island Access to Public Records Act Request: Health and mental healthcare and juvenile justice (Department Of Children, Youth And Families)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern,

This is a request for records under your state public records law.  I am requesting copies of public records regarding health and behavioural health service delivery in youth correctional facilities in your jurisdiction, to inform a comparative research project regarding health and mental health care delivery in juvenile detention facilities across the US. Specifically, I request information regarding the following:
1. Name and contact details for those responsible for health and behavioural health services provisions at all locations where juveniles are incarcerated within your jurisdiction.
2. Regulations, policies and procedures that govern the operation of health and behavioral health provision for juveniles incarcerated within your jurisdiction. This includes health intake, room confinement, medication management,  access to specialist and dental services, discharge planning services, and other health and behavioral health related policies.
3. Contracts from January 1, 2021 to the time the request is filled between your agency and any healthcare provider including both physical health and behavioral health. 
4. Records concerning your jurisdiction’s most recent application to Centre for Medicaid Services (CMS) for an 1115 Medicaid waiver (if applicable), and any response, with specifically focus on how and whether such a waiver applies to provision of Medicaid funded services for detained juveniles.
5. Records relating to financing for health and behavioural health care delivery in your jurisdiction. 

I request the records be provided electronically. If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me. However, I would also like to request a waiver of all fees in that the disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will contribute significantly to the public’s understanding of the administration of juvenile justice. This information is not being sought for commercial purposes.

If access to the records I am requesting will take longer than allowed by statute, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies of the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Thank you for considering my request.

Sincerely,

Tess Kelly 
Fellow, Harvard FXB Centre for Health and Human Rights 

Joshua Dankoff
Director of Strategic Initiatives
Citizens for Juvenile Justice
617.338.1050

title: Freedom of Information Request

communications.subject: Maryland Public Information Act Request: Freedom of Information Request
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Maryland Public Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

In the operating budget for the school districts FY 2022-2023 for employ fringe benefits list tuition reimbursement. I am looking for a list of names and the amount refunded of those employees who benefited from this bonus within the school districts FY 2022-2023 budget.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 calendar days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

M. W.

communications.subject: Public Information Act Request
communications.communication:
Attached is the information you referenced in your Public Information Act request dated June 23, 2023.

In 2022-2023, Carroll County Public Schools paid 771 employees a total of $940,221.00 in tuition reimbursements in accordance with the terms of various negotiated collective bargaining agreements between the Board of Education and employee bargaining groups.

According to our legal counsel, when the name is tied with the receipt of a personnel benefit, it is considered a personnel record and is excluded from production under the MPIA. Therefore, we have not provided the names of employees receiving tuition reimbursement.


Carey Gaddis

communications.subject: Georgia Open Records Act Request: The Georgia Department of Community Affairs
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am looking for the job description of Housing Specialist Valerie Gelimini and her contact information including her office mailing address.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

George Johnston

communications.subject: Open Records Request :: R000661-070623
communications.communication:
Dear George Johnston: 
Your request has been received and is being processed. Per GORA law, our response is due three business days after the day we receive the request. Your request was received in this office on 7/6/2023 and given the reference number R000661-070623 for tracking purposes. 
 Records Requested: Pursuant to the Georgia Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

I am looking for the job description of Housing Specialist Valerie Gelimini and her contact information including her office mailing address.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 3 business days, as the statute requires.

title: ATM Skimmers Target Standalone ATMs with Wiretap Devices

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: ATM Skimmers Target Standalone ATMs with Wiretap Devices
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Records mentioning or describing ATM skimming as a type/method of criminal behavior, as described in the 19 May 2016 Liaison Information Report (LIR) titled "ATM Skimmers Target Standalone ATMs with Wiretap Devices."

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Emma Best

Waiver Explanation

Documentation Files

Request Information

    records:
    
    Records mentioning or describing ATM skimming as a type/method of criminal
    behavior, as described in the 19 May 2016 Liaison Information Report (LIR)
    titled "ATM Skimmers Target Standalone ATMs with Wiretap Devices."
    
    The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and
    this request is not being made for commercial purposes.
    
    In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me
    of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the
    request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM
    if not.
    
    Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look
    forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days,
    as the statute requires.
    
    Sincerely,
    
    Emma Best
    
    Attachments:
    
    
    https://cdn.muckrock.com/outbound_composer_attachments/TheEmmaBest/71238/Fee20category20and20search20parameters.pdf
    
    https://cdn.muckrock.com/outbound_composer_attachments/TheEmmaBest/71238/FBI-WiretapATMs.pdf
    Upload documents directly:
    https://https://www.muckrock.comhttps://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Ffederal-bureau-of-investigation-10%252Fatm-skimmers-target-standalone-atms-with-wiretap-devices-74848%252F%253Femail%253Dfoipaquestions%252540ic.fbi.gov&url_auth_token=AAAj2ProGzquHYFeb-SMkiAXsEc%3A1hYPvi%3Aej_CxU3BXL9vwR_Gf_lcv8vRKNY

** 

Please be advised that efoia@subscriptions.fbi.gov is a no-reply email
address. Questions regarding your FOIA request may be directed to
foipaquestions@fbi.gov. If you have received a FOIPA request number, please
include this in all correspondence concerning your request. Please note eFOIPA
requests are processed in the order that they are received. If you have not
received a FOIPA request number, your request is in the process of being
opened at which time it will be assigned a FOIPA request number and
correspondence will be forthcoming.

** 

Upon receipt of your FOIPA request number, you may check the status of your
FOIPA request on the FBI’s electronic FOIA Library (The Vault) on the FBI’s
public website, http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on the ‘Check Status of Your
FOI/PA Request tool’ link. Status updates are performed on a weekly basis. If
you receive a comment that your FOIPA request number was not located in the
database, please check back at a later date.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: ATM Skimmers Target Standalone ATMs with Wiretap Devices
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@ic.fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 138 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 571 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,289 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,649 days for processing.

Respectfully,

Public Information Officer
Record/Information Dissemination Section (RIDS) FBI-Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive, Winchester, VA 22602-4843
Direct: (540) 868-4593
Fax: (540) 868-4391
Questions E-mail: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request #1438981-000
communications.communication:
Thank you for contacting foipaquestions@fbi.gov.  Please check the status of your FOIPA Request at http://vault.fbi.gov by clicking on "Check Status of Your FOI/PA Request" on the right side of the page, and follow the instructions below.

Check the Status of Your FOIPA Request
If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-0] please enter [1234567-000] into the system. If your FOIPA Number is [1234567-1] please enter [1234567-001] into the system. If you have any questions about the status of your FOIPA request, please e-mail foipaquestions@ic.fbi.gov.

FIND STATUS OF FOIPA- Request statuses are updated weekly

Please enter the whole FOIPA number-Example: [1234567-000]

FOIPA:
Results will show the Request Number, Case Type and Process Description shown below:
FOIPA:
1234567-000

Case Type:
FOIPA

Process Description (Will display the current progress of the request)
The FBI's FOIPA Program is searching the FBI's indices for potentially responsive documents.
You may be contacted via formal letter for all fees and/or negotiation issues that may apply.

NOTE: Recent requests are entered into the FOIPA database in the order that they are received. Before you can check the status, you must have received correspondence assigning a FOIPA request number and the information transferred to the online database. Status information is updated weekly. If a request has been closed within the last six months the online database will display the following: The FOIPA number entered has been closed, and appropriate correspondence has been sent to the address on file.

Estimated Dates of Completion
Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium, large, and extra-large sub-tracks based upon request size.  Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  Currently, simple track cases average approximately 138 days from the date of receipt for processing.  Our complex requests in the medium processing track are currently averaging 571 days, large processing track are currently averaging approximately 1,289 days, and extra-large processing track are currently averaging 1,649 days for processing.

Respectfully,


Public Information Officer
FBI - Information Management Division
170 Marcel Drive
Winchester, VA  22602
O: (540) 868-4593
F: (540) 868-4391
E: foipaquestions@fbi.gov<mailto:foipaquestions@fbi.gov>

Do you have further questions about the FOI/PA process? Visit us at http://www.fbi.gov/foia

Please check the status of your request online at https://vault.fbi.gov/fdps-1/@@search-fdps    Status updates are performed on a weekly basis.

Note:  This is a non-emergency email address.  If this is an emergency, please call 911 directly.  If you need to report a tip for immediate action, please contact FBI Tips at http://tips.fbi.gov/ or reach out to your local field office.

title: Public Records Request - Automated Traffic Safety Program - Everett, WA

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Public Records Request - Automated Traffic Safety Program - Everett, WA
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

Evaluation scores/notes related to all proposers, submitted responses of all proposers, and debrief documents related to all proposers related to the Automated Traffic Safety Program RFP#2022-002 that was awarded on 12/23/2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Kory Saulnier

communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of June 07, 2023, Reference # D003301-060723 
Dear Kory, 
The City of Everett received a public records request from you on June 07, 2023. You requested the following: 
Our procedure is to locate records, review them for exemptions, and then prepare them for your inspection and/or copying. The undersigned will be coordinating with other City departments in the collection, review and production of responsive records. You originally submitted this request to the Everett Police Department, which is not the correct department that manages these records. It has been transferred to the City Clerk's Department to be processed. We reasonably believe that public records (if any) responsive to this request will be available on or before 6/27/2023.  If public records become available in advance of this estimate we will contact you promptly.  Conversely, if the City of Everett encounters a need to extend our estimate, we will contact you promptly with a revised estimated date. 
Thank you for your patience in awaiting this information. 
Sincerely, 
City Clerk's Office

title: Institutional Press Policies (Milwaukee Area Technical College)

communications.subject: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Institutional Press Policies (Milwaukee Area Technical College)
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Wisconsin Open Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1. Any policy, guidance, handbook, manual, or standard contract concerning the institution’s interactions or relationship with members of the news media, reporters, or journalists, including student journalists. 

2. Any policy, guidance, handbook, or manual concerning the interactions or communications of institutional employees, including faculty, administrators, staff, and student employees, with the news media, reporters, or journalists, including student journalists. 

Please note that this request does not seek a search of faculty or student email accounts or records. These requests should in no way be construed to include a review or search of email accounts, websites, or other forms of data or document retention which are controlled by students, alumni, or faculty members, nor by governmental or advisory bodies controlled by the same, except insofar as any such individuals also serve in an administrative capacity and the records were created or are held by the individual in that capacity. Any search should be limited to documents held by the administration and/or its staff members, including records created or maintained by persons acting in the capacity of administrators or staff members.

This request is made on behalf of the Foundation for Individual Rights and Expression, a nonprofit and nonpartisan organization that aims to defend and sustain the individual rights of all Americans to free speech and free thought. This request concerns a matter of public interest. The records are sought for the purpose of researching and educating the public about policies affecting student journalists' ability to engage in news gathering and reporting on college and university campuses.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Anne Marie Tamburro

communications.subject: Re: Wisconsin Open Records Act Request: Institutional Press Policies (Milwaukee Area Technical College)
communications.communication:
Good morning,

This email is in response to your records request dated June 2, 2023. MATC
will initiate the search for these records as soon as practicable and
without delay.  Attached please find a copy of MATC District Board policy
A0109, which describes MATC policies and procedures for responding to
public records requests.

Pursuant to Wis. Stat.19.35(3), a location fee will be charged after costs
exceed fifty dollars ($50.00).  Duplicating fees for responsive records are
charged at a rate of fifteen cents ($.15) per page.  Mailing and shipping
costs are also charged when applicable.  Please be aware that pursuant to
Wis. Stat. 19.35(3)(f), MATC may require prepayment for record requests if
the total exceeds five dollars ($5.00).

We will provide you with a reasonable estimate of application fees if the
total is estimated to exceed $5.00.  You may indicate then whether you want
access to the records or copies of the records.  Upon your approval and
payment (if required) of the associated fees, we will initiate a search for
the records.  We will contact you as soon as the records have been located
and prepared for disclosure.

In the event that MATC declines to produce the requested records for any
reason, you will be notified of that denial in writing and notified of your
rights. Do not presume the passage of time between your request and MATC’s
response means that the request has been denied. If you have any questions
regarding this, please reply to this email. Thank you.

Sincerely,

Haley Rishmawi

communications.communication: You're not permitted to charge for the release as I am a member of the press, it is less than 5,000 pages and you failed to respond within the time period allowed by statute. Please process the file for full release, as-is.

communications.subject: FOIA request 1408874 (Daniel Bledsoe)
communications.communication:
Good morning Ms. Best,

We're contacting you about the FOIA request you made for records concerning Daniel Bledsoe. As you probably recall, the FBI located approximately 1330 pages that are potentially responsive to your request. Requests are processed in the order in which they are received through our multi-track processing system, and the FBI receives a voluminous amount of requests on a daily, weekly, monthly, and annual basis.  Requests are divided into two primary tracks--simple (under 50 pages of potentially responsive documents) and complex (over 50 pages of potentially responsive documents).  Complex requests are further divided into medium (51-950 pages), large (951-8000 pages), and extra-large (over 8000 pages) sub-tracks based upon request size. 

Simple track requests typically require the least amount of time to process.  The more potentially responsive pages a request has, the more complex it becomes, greatly increasing the time required for processing.  Generally, the larger the file, the longer it takes to process. A review of your request determined that it is currently in the complex request large processing track.  Given our current workload and staffing levels, it may yet be a long time before you begin to receive material from this request.   

Reducing the scope of your request may accelerate the processing and allow for a more timely receipt of the information you seek, as it could potentially place your request into a smaller, faster processing track.  This may also reduce duplication costs, if applicable.  Would you be willing to consider reducing the scope of your request?  If so, I would be happy to help you to decide the best approach to take.  We could potentially narrow your request by date, or if you are looking for something specific, we could approach the scope reduction process in that way.

Please let us know if you would like to potentially reduce the scope of your request.  We can be reached via email at fbi.foipa.negotiation@fbi.gov, or you may call 540-868-1695, Monday - Friday between the hours of 7:00am and 3:00pm Eastern time.

Best regards,

FOIA Negotiation Team
FBI Information Management Division
540-868-1695

Need a status check? Contact FOIPA Questions (foipaquestions@fbi.gov).

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Daniel Bledsoe
communications.communication: I'm afraid I need the entire file. Can you please confirm that the fee request was made in error, and the Bureau will not be attempting to charge duplication fees for this request?

communications.subject: RE: Freedom of Information Act Request: Daniel Bledsoe
communications.communication:
Good morning Ms. Best,

You were granted news media status for this request, therefore there should be no fees because the page count is less than 5,000. We will continue processing the request in full. Thank you for following up.

Best regards,

FOIA Negotiation Team
FBI Information Management Division
540-868-1695

Need a status check? Contact FOIPA Questions (foipaquestions@fbi.gov).
